posts.name: Roman A.
posts.cooked: So, weve been havig an issue fir a while, across all of our paths, that causes our robot to freeze for about half a second between the end of a pathplanner path and when our robot starts moving to pursue a note. We tried unsuccessfully to determine the cause of this but still have no idea. The command group in question (“PursueAndIntakeNoteForShooter”) does wait for our intake to extend before moving, but the paluse seems to occur regardless of the intake’s extension state, furthermore this pause is not visible when the intake is already extended and the command is used outside of our auto paths. Does anyone have any ideas?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead

posts.custom_user_title: 5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead

posts.name: Roman A.
posts.cooked: I dont think so, auto is completely brownout free in our logs, plus it only happes when switching from pre-planned motion to note persuit, not while actually moving.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead

posts.custom_user_title: 5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead

posts.cooked: Maybe it’s because Java needs time to load stuff. For example, PathPlanner recomends that in Robot.robotInit() you put, PathfindingCommand.warmupCommand().schedule() , which is just a command that generates a fake path and runs it without running it so that all the parts of the library needed are in memory.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked: Are you sure it’s not just waiting for the robot to fully stop at the end of the path? Do you have an a goal end state with a velocity >0?

posts.name: Kevin Forbes
posts.cooked: To toss more ideas out there, we recently discovered the CTRE commands for adjusting brake/coast mode, at least with v6 API, are blocking and take quite a bit of time (1/4 sec for 4 mechanisms). Unlikely to account for your whole delay, but a possible contributor.

posts.name: Dan Langdon
posts.cooked: Add a goal end state to your path which matches the speed you want your pursue note command to move at. It will cause the path to end with velocity and transition into your note command more seamlessly
Noticed this too. Definitely would not recommend teams switch between brake and coast.

posts.name: Roman A.
posts.cooked: we only do so on disable, so it should not be happening mid path

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
TheOtherGuy:

the CTRE commands for adjusting brake/coast mode, at least with v6 API, are blocking and take quite a bit of time

Are you setting these while the robot is enabled?  If so, why?

posts.name: Kevin Forbes
posts.cooked:
Several motors were set to brake on auto init and set back on disable init, so various mechanisms are easier to handle while disabled.

They’ve reworked it now to use a beam break sensor to toggle brake/coast while disabled.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked: OK.  I recommend waiting a few seconds after disabledInit .  What sort of delay are you seeing in autoInit ?

posts.name: Vaughn Khouri
posts.cooked:
I’ve seen some neat implementations of this.

I know 254 truss react climb in 2022 would set brake or coast of the elevator based on the condition of the stinger and the elevator height when match time was at almost 0. If the stinger had extended and the elevator retracted past a threshold, the motor would be set to coast and the robot would drop onto the traversal after the match. If one of those conditions was not met it would be set to brake, and the mid bar climb would count after the 5s period.

Although agreed, not necessary for 99% of teams.

posts.name: Kevin Forbes
posts.cooked:
Love these unintended side effects of small changes

They were seeing on the order of 50-70ms per call (3 Falcons on mechanisms on standard Rio CAN bus and 8 Falcons on CANivore bus at FD speeds). That added up to a quarter of a second delay at the start of auto.

posts.name: Surya Thoppae
posts.cooked:
Hahaha yes, we also had the same problem on enable and disable so we just took this out of the code before comp, you can imagine our frustration when we realized that setting brake mode on the motor had to be a blocking call.

Later, we assessed our priorities and understood that the brakeModeExecutor ( see here ) thread pool had to come into play. The safest way to do this was to synchronize over the config object as seen in the setDriveBrake() and setTurnBrake() methods. With the new addition, we can now maintain full performance in auto without sacrificing comfort, although we do incur an increase in our CANivore utilization by almost two times. I wouldn’t suggest implementing this if you have limited time, but this may be a future solution if you care about the brake mode performance feature dearly.

posts.name: Myer
posts.cooked:
This is the exact same problem I posted about earlier: PathPlanner Auto Random Delays

There are some replies that may help and I will update both threads if I find anything that works.

posts.name: Roman A.
posts.cooked: Interesting, this appears to be diffrent issue from what were experiencing, for us the pause happens entirely outhdside of our pathplanner path, when the actual follower commend ends and our pure persuit note tracker starts.
